Despite how much of a meme this game has become, it hasn't lost it's fun. The only game I have spent more time on is Skyrim and even then there are times where I prefer this one. Unlike your average FPS where a 12 year old can hop in and somehow become the world's top player. This game actually requires skill and finesse that others don't have. And unlike the game (more like meme at this point) Overwatch, you have a vast array of weapons and cosmetics that you can equip your mercenaries with. More weapons equals more play styles and that means more playability. And that means more fun. With several different modes and challenges to go play and the whole world to play with, you can see why this game is still around.
Apesar de que pasen los a√±os el juego no pierde sula encanto, talvez no lo actualicen mucho pero la comunidad lo mantiene, 10/10

After playing it for a lot of time with the game, I decided to go back and write a review about it. Before Team Fortress 2 went free to play, remember it used to be a paid game, then microtransactions were implmented in the game, and FINALLY Free to play. So what do I like about it? Well for starters it has a unique visual quality, constant updates, good community updates and maps, and Valve is trying their best to update it. Note: in order to get a key IF you get a crate that needs a key, you have to buy it. Don't get me wrong, it was bad when you have to pay it and get money to get the in-game items. But luckly Valve made it free to play, thus justifyed the micro transactions and the Unusuals in there are expensive. If you don't know what an Unusual is, I'll explain it: Unusuals are effects thare are very rare to find and even with that they are expensive to get to and due to thre rarity of Unusuals, communities have set it in keys and/or refs(refined metals). Also I forgot to mention about the unsusals: they can be founded on hats and on weapons(appeared after the gun mettle update came out). Now trading is about using ref and/or keys to get items you desire, BUT on march 15, 2016 the Mobile thing that allows you to trade faster has been enforced to trade usually, but not always.
While there a lack of constant updates due to other games that also has micro transactions, Valve has constant updates to other games lately more often then not Team fortress 2 itself. The negatives as of now is the lack of updates(maps, weapons, weapon balancing, MORE HATS, misc[a cosmetic but it isn't A HAT], and possibily new game modes or new takes on game modes), and lack of company/customer communication. Also I wanted to point out that before the meat you match update(the latest major update) you have to browse for community servers or use the play button to play like the casual game play today. I like casual more then the play game button, due to the fact that brings compentition and teamwork(depends on how well the team in total is communicating effectively). If you install the game and didn't bought items for TF2 like non-stock and non-reskin weapons you're gameplay and effeciency WILL be effected one way or another. 
Things I like about this game: Unique visuals, characters are different and unique, good enough balancing, some great maps, maps that don't need to be paid for and you can download more from the Team fortress 2 workshop in the maps tab,It's free to play, and especially cosmetics are option.
Things I don't like about the game: lack of updates, some really bad maps(not gonna tell. You got to experience the bad maps and look for bad maps in youtube or other media websites, lack of company and customer communications, non-stock weapons need to be bought(if you new to steam go to mann co store and purchase the weapon bundle(s) or if your have an exsisting account and has not played team fortress 2 ever, go to the community market and just buy a weapon[with bonuses] for a better price), in order to play compeditively either 2 options pay a competitve ticket or use the other option(click on the competitve game mode to see what options you have(if you don't have the tickets nor the other option)
DO I recommend this game? ..................YES. It's free, casual is free, maps that are, you guessed it free and as a bonus you can download more in the workshop. However if you don't like buying weapons for weapons stats difference then you MAY no like the game for that. But here's a quick tip of how to download workshop maps: subscribe to the map you want and you have to copy the map file(find the file related to the map you want[go to steamapps,workshop,content, then you see a couple of numbers. Try finding it just in case if I get you a wrong answer.) then pasted it in the maps file in the tf file(in the team fortress 2 file found in the common file after finding the steamapps file, and there you go(caution not all maps are completely finished, but some are in _rc. _rc means release candaite[misspelled it sorry]. Also I hope you have a good day after reading all this.

Muy buen juego, pero me gustaria que al momento de ser desconectado del servidor por problemas de internet no te borren los puntos, eso molesta bastante, ya en varias ocaciones me ha sacado con una buena puntuacion, se que son probleas del internet, pero si se pudieran recuperar seria estupendo, ya que asi comovoy dudo pueda subir de nivel ya por las condiciones dichas anteriormente, aparte de eso nada mas que resaltar, es una gran obra y esta genial, gracias por su atencion. ;)

[b]I'll put here a tutorial to cook rice:[/b]

You will need : measuring cup, water, saucepan with lid, salt, rice, wooden spoon and a fork.

Follow These Steps

 1.Boil water and add salt
Pour water (for every cup of rice, use 1 3/4 cups of water) into a large saucepan with a tight-fitting lid. Bring to a boil. Mix 1 teaspoon salt into the water.
    
2.Pour in rice
Add it to the boiling water.
    
3.Stir once, or just enough to separate the rice
Use a wooden spoon to separate any clumps. Don‚Äôt over-stir: That can cause the rice to become sticky.
 
4.Cover the pot and simmer
Be sure the lid fits tightly on the pot. Turn down the heat to its lowest setting. Let rice simmer for about 18 minutes, then remove from heat and allow the rice to steam in the pot for another 5 minutes.
    
5.Fluff rice with a fork
Just before serving, gently fluff the rice with a fork to separate the grains.

Tip: Don‚Äôt uncover the saucepan or stir the rice during cooking. If it‚Äôs done before you‚Äôre ready to serve it, place a folded towel over the saucepan, replace the lid, and set aside. The towel will absorb excess moisture and condensation, helping prevent overcooked and mushy rice.

[i]Enjoy your top notch rice while playing this great game[/i]
